newsitem.title: USA: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.5 pct in April--Redbook.
newsitem.headline: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.5 pct in April--Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 0.5 percent for the first two weeks of fiscal April versus March, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook Retail Sales Index.
The index rose 6.4 percent compared with the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales rose 6.2 percent in the week ended April 19 compared with the same week a year ago, it said.

Most retailers in the Redbook survey fell modestly short of plan for the week, and continued to characterize sales for April to date as "disappointing," said Howard Eilenberg, a retail analyst at Redbook Research.

"It's just a continuation of a slowdown that we've had for the last couple of weeks," Eilenberg said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television. "The exuberance that we saw in February and in early March just isn't there anymore," he said.

Despite the modest slowdown in retail sales, national department stores improved slightly, Eilenberg said. "(National department stores) looked better the second week than the first week," he said, adding that they were on plan for the month.
"It was the discounters that took a little stumble this past week ... a lot of them underplanned for week and the month-to-date," he said.
Eilenberg noted the slump in discount sales was mostly attributed to the harsh winter-like weather in the Midwest.
Meanwhile, other regions showed no signs of weak sales.
"It was the Midwest that kind of dragged everything down," Eilenberg added.
